context: They crossed a hill. At the foot of the hill flowed a brook, and when they had crossed the brook they had to climb another hill. Gradually the landscape changed. From the top of the hill could be seen a valley, level in the middle, surrounded by abrupt crags and shaded by green trees, among which houses and towers peeped forth. This was the country house of Old Dschang. Before the village flowed a deep brook full of clear, blue water. They passed over a stone bridge and reached the gate. Here flowers and trees grew in luxurious profusion, and peacocks and cranes flew about. From the distance could be heard the sound of flutes and of stringed instruments. Crystal-clear tones rose to the clouds. A messenger in a purple robe received the guest at the gate and led him into a hall of surpassing splendor. Strange fragrances filled the air, and there was a ringing of little bells of pearl. Two maid-servants came forth to greet him, followed by two rows of beautiful girls in a long processional. After them a man in a flowing turban, clad in scarlet silk, with red slippers, came floating along. The guest saluted him. He was serious and dignified, and at the same time seemed youthfully fresh. At first We's son did not recognize him, but when he looked more closely, why it was Old Dschang! The latter said with a smile: "I am pleased that the long road to travel has not prevented your coming. Your sister is just combing her hair. She will welcome you in a moment." Then he had him sit down and drink tea.

qas.question: Why didn't Sir We's son recognize Old Dschang?

context: After a short time a maid-servant came and led him to the inner rooms, to his sister. The beams of her room were of sandalwood, the doors of tortoise-shell and the windows inlaid with blue jade; her curtains were formed of strings of pearls and the steps leading into the room of green nephrite. His sister was magnificently gowned, and far more beautiful than before. She asked him carelessly how he was getting along, and what her parents were doing; but was not very cordial. After a splendid meal she had an apartment prepared for him.  "My sister wishes to make an excursion to the Mountain of the Fairies," said Old Dschang to him. "We will be back about sunset, and you can rest until we return."

context: After a short time a maid-servant came and led him to the inner rooms, to his sister. The beams of her room were of sandalwood, the doors of tortoise-shell and the windows inlaid with blue jade; her curtains were formed of strings of pearls and the steps leading into the room of green nephrite. His sister was magnificently gowned, and far more beautiful than before. She asked him carelessly how he was getting along, and what her parents were doing; but was not very cordial. After a splendid meal she had an apartment prepared for him.  "My sister wishes to make an excursion to the Mountain of the Fairies," said Old Dschang to him. "We will be back about sunset, and you can rest until we return."Then many-colored clouds rose in the courtyard, and dulcet music sounded on the air. Old Dschang mounted a dragon, while his wife and sister rode on phenixes and their attendants on cranes. So they rose into the air and disappeared in an easterly direction. They did not return until after sunset.  Old Dschang and his wife then said to him: "This is an abode of the blessed. You cannot remain here overlong. To-morrow we will escort you back."  On the following day, when taking leave, Old Dschang gave him eighty ounces of gold and an old straw hat. "Should you need money," said he, "you can go to Yangdschou and inquire in the northern suburb for old Wang's drug-shop. There you can collect ten million pieces of copper. This hat is the order for them." Then he ordered his plow-boy to take him home again.

So they rose into the air and disappeared in an easterly direction. They did not return until after sunset.  Old Dschang and his wife then said to him: "This is an abode of the blessed. You cannot remain here overlong. To-morrow we will escort you back."  On the following day, when taking leave, Old Dschang gave him eighty ounces of gold and an old straw hat. "Should you need money," said he, "you can go to Yangdschou and inquire in the northern suburb for old Wang's drug-shop. There you can collect ten million pieces of copper. This hat is the order for them." Then he ordered his plow-boy to take him home again.Quite a few of the folks at home, to whom he described his adventures, thought that Old Dschang must be a holy man, while others regarded the whole thing a magic vision.  After five or six years Sir We's money came to an end. So his son took the straw hat to Yangdschou and there asked for old Wang. The latter just happened to be standing in his drug-shop, mixing herbs. When the son explained his errand he said: "The money is ready. But is your hat genuine?" And he took the hat and examined it. A young girl came from an inner room and said: "I wove the hat for Old Dschang myself. There must be a red thread in it." And sure enough, there was. Then old Wang gave young We the ten million pieces of copper, and the latter now believed that Old Dschang was really a saint. So he once more went over the hills to look for him. He asked the forest-keepers, but they could tell him naught. Sadly he retraced his steps and decided to inquire of old Wang, but he had also disappeared.

qas.question: What will Sir We's son do when he needs money?
qas.answer: take the straw hat to Yangdschou and there ask for old Wang .

abstract_70: In a mystical courtyard, many-colored clouds arose as dulcet music filled the air. Old Dschang mounted a dragon, while his wife and sister rode phenixes, and their attendants traveled on cranes. They soared into the eastern sky, returning only after sunset. They informed their guest that this was a blessed abode where he couldn't remain long. Before departing the next day, Old Dschang presented him with eighty ounces of gold and a significant straw hat, instructing him to visit old Wang's drug-shop in Yangdschou's northern suburb where he could collect ten million copper pieces using the hat as an order. A plow-boy was ordered to escort him home. While some locals believed Old Dschang to be a holy man after hearing the tale, others dismissed it as magical illusion. Years later, when money ran short, the son took the straw hat to Yangdschou seeking old Wang. At the drug-shop, a young girl confirmed the hat's authenticity by identifying her own weaving with a red thread, leading to the promised payment. Though convinced of Old Dschang's divine nature, the son's subsequent attempts to locate either Old Dschang in the hills or old Wang proved unsuccessful, as both had vanished without trace.

Before sending his guest home, Old Dschang gifted him eighty ounces of gold and a special straw hat, which served as a token to collect ten million copper pieces from old Wang's drug-shop in Yangdschou. Years later, when Sir We's son used the hat to claim the money, a young girl confirmed its authenticity by identifying her own weaving with a red thread. Though the son later attempted to find Old Dschang and Wang again, both had mysteriously vanished, leaving people to debate whether Old Dschang was truly a holy man or if the entire experience was merely a magical illusion.

context: There was once a King and a Queen in Rousay who had three daughters. When the young Princesses were just grown up, the King died, and the Crown passed to a distant cousin, who had always hated him, and who paid no heed to the widowed Queen and her daughters.So they were left very badly off, and they went to live in a tinycottage, and did all the housework themselves. They had a kailyard infront of the cottage, and a little field behind it, and they had a cowthat grazed in the field, and which they fed with the cabbages that grew in the kailyard. For everyone knows that to feed cows with cabbages makes them give a larger quantity of milk.But they soon discovered that some one was coming at night and stealing the cabbages, and, of course, this annoyed them very much. For they knew that if they had not cabbages to give to the cow, they would not have enough milk to sell.

context: There was once a King and a Queen in Rousay who had three daughters. When the young Princesses were just grown up, the King died, and the Crown passed to a distant cousin, who had always hated him, and who paid no heed to the widowed Queen and her daughters.So they were left very badly off, and they went to live in a tinycottage, and did all the housework themselves. They had a kailyard infront of the cottage, and a little field behind it, and they had a cowthat grazed in the field, and which they fed with the cabbages that grew in the kailyard. For everyone knows that to feed cows with cabbages makes them give a larger quantity of milk.But they soon discovered that some one was coming at night and stealing the cabbages, and, of course, this annoyed them very much. For they knew that if they had not cabbages to give to the cow, they would not have enough milk to sell.So the eldest Princess said she would take out a three-legged stool, andwrap herself in a blanket, and sit in the kailyard all night to see ifshe could catch the thief. And, although it was very cold and very dark,she did so.At first it seemed as if all her trouble would be in vain, for hourafter hour passed and nothing happened. But in the small hours of themorning, just as the clock was striking two, she heard a stealthytrampling in the field behind, as if some very heavy person were tryingto tread very softly, and presently a mighty Giant stepped right overthe wall into the kailyard.He carried an enormous creel on his arm, and a large, sharp knife in hishand; and he began to cut the cabbages, and to throw them into the creel as fast as he could.

qas.question: What will the eldest Princess do after they discover someone is stealing their cabbages?
qas.answer: catch the thief .

abstract_70: In Rousay, a King and Queen had three daughters. After the King's passing, the crown transferred to a distant cousin who had always harbored hatred for the former King and showed no consideration for the widowed Queen and her daughters. Facing financial hardship, they relocated to a tiny cottage where they managed all household duties themselves. The cottage had a kailyard in front and a small field behind, where they kept a cow that grazed and was fed with cabbages from their kailyard - a known practice for increasing milk production. Their livelihood was threatened when they discovered someone was stealing their cabbages at night, which would directly impact their ability to feed the cow and produce milk for sale. The eldest Princess took initiative, deciding to guard the kailyard through the night. Armed with a three-legged stool and wrapped in a blanket, she maintained her watch in the cold darkness. After many uneventful hours, at two in the morning, she heard stealthy footsteps in the field, followed by the appearance of a massive Giant who stepped over the wall. The Giant, carrying an enormous creel and a sharp knife, began rapidly cutting and collecting their cabbages.

The eldest Princess decided to keep watch and discovered a Giant was the thief, who came at 2 AM with a large creel and knife to steal their cabbages.

context: So the eldest Princess said she would take out a three-legged stool, andwrap herself in a blanket, and sit in the kailyard all night to see ifshe could catch the thief. And, although it was very cold and very dark,she did so.At first it seemed as if all her trouble would be in vain, for hourafter hour passed and nothing happened. But in the small hours of themorning, just as the clock was striking two, she heard a stealthytrampling in the field behind, as if some very heavy person were tryingto tread very softly, and presently a mighty Giant stepped right overthe wall into the kailyard.He carried an enormous creel on his arm, and a large, sharp knife in hishand; and he began to cut the cabbages, and to throw them into the creel as fast as he could.Now the Princess was no coward, so, although she had not expected toface a Giant, she gathered up her courage, and cried out sharply, "Whogave thee liberty to cut our cabbages? Leave off this minute, and goaway."The Giant paid no heed, but went on steadily with what he was doing."Do you not hear me?" cried the girl indignantly; for she was thePrincess Royal, and had always been accustomed to be obeyed."If you will be not quiet I will take you too," said the Giant grimly,pressing the cabbages down into the creel."I should like to see you try," retorted the Princess, rising from herstool and stamping her foot; for she felt so angry that she forgot fora moment that she was only a weak maiden and he was a great and powerfulGiant.

qas.question: What will the eldest Princess do when she sees the Giant?
qas.answer: tell him to go away .

abstract_70: The eldest Princess volunteered to catch the thief by taking a three-legged stool and wrapping herself in a blanket, determined to sit in the kailyard throughout the night. Despite the cold and dark conditions, she maintained her vigil. For many hours, nothing occurred, making her effort seem futile. However, at two o'clock in the morning, she heard stealthy but heavy footsteps in the field behind, and suddenly a mighty Giant stepped over the wall into the kailyard. He was equipped with an enormous creel on his arm and a large, sharp knife in his hand, and immediately began cutting the cabbages, tossing them into his creel with remarkable speed. The Princess, though facing an unexpected Giant, showed no fear and boldly confronted him, demanding to know who gave him permission to take their cabbages and ordering him to leave. When the Giant ignored her commands and continued his theft, threatening to take her too if she wouldn't be quiet, the Princess defiantly challenged him, momentarily forgetting in her anger that she was merely a weak maiden facing a powerful Giant.

context: Now the Princess was no coward, so, although she had not expected toface a Giant, she gathered up her courage, and cried out sharply, "Whogave thee liberty to cut our cabbages? Leave off this minute, and goaway."The Giant paid no heed, but went on steadily with what he was doing."Do you not hear me?" cried the girl indignantly; for she was thePrincess Royal, and had always been accustomed to be obeyed."If you will be not quiet I will take you too," said the Giant grimly,pressing the cabbages down into the creel."I should like to see you try," retorted the Princess, rising from herstool and stamping her foot; for she felt so angry that she forgot fora moment that she was only a weak maiden and he was a great and powerfulGiant.

context: Now the Princess was no coward, so, although she had not expected toface a Giant, she gathered up her courage, and cried out sharply, "Whogave thee liberty to cut our cabbages? Leave off this minute, and goaway."The Giant paid no heed, but went on steadily with what he was doing."Do you not hear me?" cried the girl indignantly; for she was thePrincess Royal, and had always been accustomed to be obeyed."If you will be not quiet I will take you too," said the Giant grimly,pressing the cabbages down into the creel."I should like to see you try," retorted the Princess, rising from herstool and stamping her foot; for she felt so angry that she forgot fora moment that she was only a weak maiden and he was a great and powerfulGiant.And, as if to show her how strong he was, he seized her by her arm andher leg, and put her in his creel on the top of the cabbages, andcarried her away bodily.When he reached his home, which was in a great square house on a lonely moor, he took her out, and set her down roughly on the floor."You will be my servant now," he said, "and keep my house, and do my errands for me. I have a cow, which you must drive out every day to the hillside; and see, here is a bag of wool, when you have taken out the cow, you must come back and settle thyself at home, as a good housewife should, and comb, and card it, and spin it into yarn, with which to weave a good thick cloth for my raiment. I am out most of the day, but when I come home I shall expect to find all this done, and a great bicker of porridge boiled besides for my supper."

abstract_70: The Princess, being no coward, unexpectedly faced a Giant who was cutting their cabbages. Despite her royal status and being accustomed to obedience, her sharp commands for him to stop and leave went unheeded. When she protested indignantly, the Giant threatened to take her as well. Forgetting momentarily that she was merely a weak maiden confronting a powerful Giant, she defiantly challenged him. To demonstrate his strength, the Giant seized her by arm and leg, placed her in his creel atop the cabbages, and carried her away bodily. Upon reaching his home, a great square house on a lonely moor, he roughly set her down and declared she would be his servant. Her duties were clearly outlined: she must drive his cow to the hillside daily, and then return to process wool - combing, carding, and spinning it into yarn for weaving cloth for his garments. The Giant, who was absent most days, expected to find all these tasks completed and a large portion of porridge prepared for his supper upon his return.

context: The poor Princess was very dismayed when she heard these words, for she had never been accustomed to work hard, and she had always had her sisters to help her; but the Giant took no notice of her distress, butwent out as soon as it was daylight, leaving her alone in the house tobegin her work.As soon as he had gone she drove the cow to the pasture, as he had told her to do; but she had a good long walk over the moor before she reached the hill, and by the time that she got back to the house she felt very tired.So she thought that she would put on the porridge pot, and make herself some porridge before she began to card and comb the wool. She did so, and just as she was sitting down to sup them the door opened, and a crowd of wee, wee Peerie Folk came in.

context: They were the tiniest men and women that the Princess had ever seen; not one of them would have reached half-way to her knee; and they were dressed in dresses fashioned out of all the colours of therainbow--scarlet and blue, green and yellow, orange and violet; and thefunny thing was, that every one of them had a shock of straw-colouredyellow hair.They were all talking and laughing with one another; and they hopped up, first on stools, then on chairs, till at last they reached the top ofthe table, where they clustered round the bowl, out of which thePrincess was eating her porridge."We be hungry, we be hungry," they cried, in their tiny shrill voices."Spare a little porridge for the Peerie Folk."

context: After this she finished her porridge in peace; then she took the woolout of the bag, and she set to work to comb and card it. But it seemedas if it were bewitched; it curled and twisted and coiled itself roundher fingers so that, try as she would, she could not do anything withit. And when the Giant came home he found her sitting in despair with it all in confusion round her, and the porridge, which she had left for him in the pot, burned to a cinder.As you may imagine, he was very angry, and raged, and stamped, and used the most dreadful words; and at last he took her by the heels, and beat her until all her back was skinned and bleeding; then he carried her out to the byre, and threw her up on the joists among the hens. And, although she was not dead, she was so stunned and bruised that she could only lie there motionless, looking down on the backs of the cows.Time went on, and in the kailyard at home the cabbages were disappearing as fast as ever. So the second Princess said that she would do as her sister had done, and wrap herself in a blanket, and go and sit on a three-legged stool all night, to see what was becoming of them.

context: She did so, and exactly the same fate befell her that had befallen herelder sister. The Giant appeared with his creel, and he carried heroff, and set her to mind the cow and the house, and to make his porridge and to spin; and the little yellow-headed Peerie Folk appeared and asked her for some supper, and she refused to give it to them; and after that, she could not comb or card her wool, and the Giant was angry, and he scolded her, and beat her, and threw her up, half dead, on the joists beside her sister and the hens.Then the youngest Princess determined to sit out in the kailyard allnight, not so much to see what was becoming of the cabbages, as todiscover what had happened to her sisters.And when the Giant came and carried her off, she was not at all sorry,but very glad, for she was a brave and loving little maiden; and now shefelt that she had a chance of finding out where they were, and whetherthey were dead or alive.

context: So she was quite cheerful and happy, for she felt certain that she wasclever enough to outwit the Giant, if only she were watchful andpatient; so she lay quite quietly in her creel above the cabbages, butshe kept her eyes very wide open to see by which road he was carryingher off.And when he set her down in his kitchen, and told her all that heexpected her to do, she did not look downcast like her sisters, butnodded her head brightly, and said that she felt sure that she could doit.And she sang to herself as she drove the cow over the moor to pasture,and she ran the whole way back, so that she should have a good longafternoon to work at the wool, and, although she would not have told the Giant this, to search the house.

context: Before she set to work, however, she made herself some porridge, just as her sisters had done; and, just as she was going to sup them, all thelittle yellow-haired Peerie Folk trooped in, and climbed up on thetable, and stood and stared at her."We be hungry, we be hungry," they cried. "Spare a little porridge forthe Peerie Folk.""With all my heart," replied the good-natured Princess. "If you can finddishes little enough for you to sup out of, I will fill them for you.But, it seems to me, if I were to give you all porringers, you would smotheryourselves among the porridge."

context: She did so, and exactly the same fate befell her that had befallen herelder sister. The Giant appeared with his creel, and he carried heroff, and set her to mind the cow and the house, and to make his porridge and to spin; and the little yellow-headed Peerie Folk appeared and asked her for some supper, and she refused to give it to them; and after that, she could not comb or card her wool, and the Giant was angry, and he scolded her, and beat her, and threw her up, half dead, on the joists beside her sister and the hens.Then the youngest Princess determined to sit out in the kailyard allnight, not so much to see what was becoming of the cabbages, as todiscover what had happened to her sisters.And when the Giant came and carried her off, she was not at all sorry,but very glad, for she was a brave and loving little maiden; and now shefelt that she had a chance of finding out where they were, and whetherthey were dead or alive.So she was quite cheerful and happy, for she felt certain that she wasclever enough to outwit the Giant, if only she were watchful andpatient; so she lay quite quietly in her creel above the cabbages, butshe kept her eyes very wide open to see by which road he was carryingher off.And when he set her down in his kitchen, and told her all that heexpected her to do, she did not look downcast like her sisters, butnodded her head brightly, and said that she felt sure that she could doit.And she sang to herself as she drove the cow over the moor to pasture,and she ran the whole way back, so that she should have a good longafternoon to work at the wool, and, although she would not have told the Giant this, to search the house.

qas.question: Why did the youngest Princess search the Giant's house?
qas.answer: She wanted to find her sisters. .

abstract_70: A young Princess encountered the same fate as her elder sister when a Giant appeared with his creel and carried her away. The Giant assigned her tasks: minding the cow, keeping the house, making porridge, and spinning wool. When the yellow-headed Peerie Folk appeared and requested supper, she refused to help them. As a consequence, she found herself unable to comb or card her wool properly. The angry Giant scolded and beat her, ultimately throwing her, half-dead, onto the joists beside her sister and the hens. The youngest Princess, determined to uncover the truth, decided to sit in the kailyard all night, less concerned about the cabbages than discovering her sisters' whereabouts. Being brave and loving, she was actually glad when the Giant carried her off, seeing it as an opportunity to find her sisters. Unlike her siblings, she remained cheerful and confident, knowing she could outsmart the Giant with patience and watchfulness. She stayed alert in her creel above the cabbages, carefully observing the route. When placed in the Giant's kitchen and given her tasks, she responded positively, nodding brightly and expressing confidence. She demonstrated her efficiency by singing while tending to the cow, running back quickly to ensure ample time for wool-working and secretly exploring the house.
abstract_30: The story follows three princesses who encounter a Giant. The first two sisters were captured by the Giant and forced to tend to his house, make porridge, and spin wool. When visited by the Peerie Folk asking for supper, they refused, leading to their inability to work with wool. The Giant punished them by beating them and leaving them half-dead. The youngest princess, being brave and clever, deliberately allowed herself to be captured to find her sisters. Unlike her siblings, she remained cheerful and confident in her ability to outsmart the Giant, carefully observing her surroundings and attending to her tasks while planning to search the house.
fully_response: The youngest Princess searched the Giant's house to find out what had happened to her sisters, determine if they were alive or dead, and potentially rescue them.
roughly_response: The youngest Princess searched the Giant's house to find out where her sisters were and whether they were dead or alive.
abstract_response: The youngest Princess searched the Giant's house because she was determined to find her missing sisters and uncover the truth about their disappearance. Unlike her sisters, she was brave and strategic, using the opportunity of being captured by the Giant to locate them.
partially_response: The youngest princess searched the Giant's house to find and rescue her captured sisters.
blank_response: To find something lost or save someone captured.

context: At her words the Peerie Folk shouted with laughter, till theirstraw-coloured hair tumbled right over their faces; then they hopped on to the floor and ran out of the house, and presently they came trooping back holding cups of blue-bells, and foxgloves, and saucers of primroses and anemones in their hands; and the Princess put a tiny spoonful of porridge into each saucer, and a tiny drop of milk into each cup, and they ate it all up as daintily as possible with neat little grassspoons, which they had brought with them in their pockets.When they had finished they all cried out, "Thank you! Thank you!" andran out of the kitchen again, leaving the Princess alone. And, beingalone, she went all over the house to look for her sisters, but, ofcourse, she could not find them."Never mind, I will find them soon," she said to herself. "To-morrow Iwill search the byre and the outhouses; in the meantime, I had betterget on with my work." So she went back to the kitchen, and took out the bag of wool, which the Giant had told her to make into cloth.

qas.answer: cups of blue-bells, and foxgloves, and saucers of primroses and anemones .

qas.answer: put a tiny spoonful of porridge into each saucer, and a tiny drop of milk into each cup .

abstract_70: At her words, the Peerie Folk burst into such laughter that their straw-colored hair fell over their faces. They hopped to the floor and ran out, soon returning with cups made of blue-bells and foxgloves, and saucers crafted from primroses and anemones. The Princess served them each a tiny portion of porridge and milk, which they ate daintily using small grass spoons they had brought in their pockets. After finishing their meal, they all called out their thanks and departed, leaving the Princess by herself. Finding herself alone, she searched throughout the house for her sisters but couldn't locate them anywhere. Remaining hopeful, she decided to continue her search in the byre and outhouses the following day. For the time being, she returned to the kitchen to work on the task the Giant had given her: making cloth from the bag of wool.

Left alone, the Princess searched unsuccessfully for her sisters throughout the house. Remaining optimistic, she decided to continue her task of making cloth from the Giant's wool while planning to search the byre and outhouses the next day.

context: But just as she was doing so the door opened once more, and aYellow-Haired Peerie Boy entered. He was exactly like the other PeerieFolk who had eaten the Princess's porridge, only he was bigger, and hewore a very rich dress of grass-green velvet. He walked boldly into themiddle of the kitchen and looked round him."Do you have any work for me to do?" he asked. "I know grand how to handle wool and turn it into fine thick cloth.""I have plenty of work for anybody who asks it," replied the Princess;"but I have no money to pay for it, and there are but few folk in thisworld who will work without wages.""All the wages that I ask is that tyou will take the trouble to find outmy name, for few folk ken it, and few folk care to know. But if by anychance you cannot find it out, then must you pay toll of half ofyour cloth."

abstract_70: At the Princess's words, the Peerie Folk burst into laughter, their straw-colored hair falling over their faces. They brought cups made of blue-bells and foxgloves, and saucers of primroses and anemones. The Princess served them tiny portions of porridge and milk, which they ate daintily with grass spoons they had brought. After finishing and expressing their thanks, they left the Princess alone. She searched throughout the house for her sisters but couldn't find them. Remaining optimistic, she decided to continue her work with the wool the Giant had given her, planning to search the byre and outhouses the next day. As she was about to begin, a Yellow-Haired Peerie Boy entered the kitchen. He was larger than the other Peerie Folk and wore fine grass-green velvet. He confidently offered to help turn the wool into fine thick cloth, asking only one thing in return - that she discover his name, which few knew or cared to know. However, he warned that if she failed to learn his name, she would have to give him half of her cloth as payment.
abstract_30: A Princess encounters the Peerie Folk, tiny creatures with straw-colored hair, who share a miniature meal served in flower cups and saucers. After they leave, she searches unsuccessfully for her sisters in the house. While attempting to make cloth from wool as instructed by a Giant, she meets a Yellow-Haired Peerie Boy dressed in green velvet. He offers to help with the wool-working, asking only that she discover his name as payment, or else forfeit half her cloth if she fails.

context: But just as she was doing so the door opened once more, and aYellow-Haired Peerie Boy entered. He was exactly like the other PeerieFolk who had eaten the Princess's porridge, only he was bigger, and hewore a very rich dress of grass-green velvet. He walked boldly into themiddle of the kitchen and looked round him."Do you have any work for me to do?" he asked. "I know grand how to handle wool and turn it into fine thick cloth.""I have plenty of work for anybody who asks it," replied the Princess;"but I have no money to pay for it, and there are but few folk in thisworld who will work without wages.""All the wages that I ask is that tyou will take the trouble to find outmy name, for few folk ken it, and few folk care to know. But if by anychance you cannot find it out, then must you pay toll of half ofyour cloth."The Princess thought that it would be quite an easy thing to find outthe Boy's name, so she agreed to the bargain, and, putting all the woolback into the bag, she gave it to him, and he swung it over his shoulderand departed.She ran to the door to see where he went, for she had made up her mind that she would follow him secretly to his home, and find out from the neighbours what his name was.But, to her great dismay, though she looked this way and that, he hadvanished completely, and she began to wonder what she should do if the Giant came back and found that she had allowed someone, whose name she did not even know, to carry off all the wool.And, as the afternoon wore on, and she could think of no way of findingout who the boy was, or where he came from, she felt that she had made a great mistake, and she began to grow very frightened.

qas.answer: He will help her complete the task. .

abstract_70: As the Princess was going about her business, the door opened and a Yellow-Haired Peerie Boy entered the kitchen. He was similar to the other Peerie Folk who had eaten her porridge before, but was larger and wore an elegant grass-green velvet dress. Walking confidently into the kitchen, he offered his services in handling wool and turning it into fine thick cloth. The Princess admitted she had plenty of work but no money to pay wages, noting that few would work without payment. The boy proposed an unusual arrangement: his only wage would be for her to discover his name, which few knew or cared to know. However, if she failed to find out his name, she would have to give up half of her cloth as payment. Believing it would be a simple task to learn his name, the Princess agreed to the deal and handed him the bag of wool. context: The Princess thought that it would be quite an easy thing to find outthe Boy's name, so she agreed to the bargain, and, putting all the woolback into the bag, she gave it to him, and he swung it over his shoulderand departed.She ran to the door to see where he went, for she had made up her mind that she would follow him secretly to his home, and find out from the neighbours what his name was.But, to her great dismay, though she looked this way and that, he hadvanished completely, and she began to wonder what she should do if the Giant came back and found that she had allowed someone, whose name she did not even know, to carry off all the wool.And, as the afternoon wore on, and she could think of no way of findingout who the boy was, or where he came from, she felt that she had made a great mistake, and she began to grow very frightened.

context: Just as the gloaming was beginning to fall a knock came at the door,and, when she opened it, she found an old woman standing outside, who begged for a night's lodging.Now, as I have told you, the Princess was very kind-hearted, and shewould fain have granted the poor old Dame's request, but she dared not, for she did not know what the Giant would say. So she told the old woman that she could not take her in for the night, as she was only a servant, and not the mistress of the house; but she made her sit down on a bench beside the door, and brought her out some bread and milk, and gave her some water to bathe her poor, tired feet.She was so bonnie, and gentle, and kind, and she looked so sorry whenshe told her that she would need to turn her away, that the old womangave her her blessing, and told her not to vex herself, as it was afine, dry night, and now that she had had a meal she could easily sitdown somewhere and sleep in the shelter of the outhouses.

context: And, when she had finished her bread and milk, she went and laid down by the side of a green knowe, which rose out of the moor not very far from the byre door.And, strange to say, as she lay there she felt the earth beneath hergetting warmer and warmer, until she was so hot that she was fain tocrawl up the side of the hillock, in the hope of getting a mouthful offresh air.And as she got near the top she heard a voice, which seemed to come from somewhere beneath her, saying, "TEASE, TEASENS, TEASE; CARD, CARDENS, CARD; SPIN, SPINNENS, SPIN; for PEERIFOOL PEERIFOOL, PEERIFOOL is what men call me." And when she got to the very top, she found that there was a crack in the earth, through which rays of light were coming; and when she put her eye to the crack, what should she see down below her but a brilliantly lighted chamber, in which all the Peerie Folk were sitting in a circle, working away as hard as they could.

context: Some of them were carding wool, some of them were combing it, some ofthem were spinning it, constantly wetting their fingers with their lips,in order to twist the yarn fine as they drew it from the distaff, andsome of them were spinning the yarn into cloth.While round and round the circle, cracking a little whip, and urgingthem to work faster, was a Yellow-Haired Peerie Boy."This is a strange thing, and these be queer on-goings," said the oldwoman to herself, creeping hastily down to the bottom of the hillockagain. "I must e'en go and tell the bonnie lassie in the house yonder.Maybe the knowledge of what I have seen will stand her in good steadsome day. When there be Peerie Folk about, it is well to be on one'sguard."

context: So she went back to the house and told the Princess all that she hadseen and heard, and the Princess was so delighted with what she had told her that she risked the Giant's wrath and allowed her to go and sleep in the hayloft.It was not very long after the old woman had gone to rest before thedoor opened, and the Peerie Boy appeared once more with a number of webs of cloth upon his shoulder. "Here is your cloth," he said, with a sly smile, "and I will put it on the shelf for thee the moment that youtell me what my name is."Then the Princess, who was a merry maiden, thought that she would tease the little follow for a time ere she let him know that she had found out his secret.

context: So she mentioned first one name and then another, always pretending to think that she had hit upon the right one; and all the time the PeerieBoy jumped from side to side with delight, for he thought that she would never find out the right name, and that half of the cloth would be his.But at last the Princess grew tired of joking, and she cried out, with alittle laugh of triumph, "Do you by any chance know anyone calledPEERIFOOL, little Mannikin?"Then he knew that in some way she had found out what men called him, and he was so angry and disappointed that he flung the webs of cloth down in a heap on the floor, and ran out at the door, slamming it behind him.Meanwhile the Giant was coming down the hill in the darkening, and, to his astonishment, he met a troop of little Peerie Folk toiling up it,looking as if they were so tired that they could hardly get along. Theireyes were dim and listless, their heads were hanging on their breasts,and their lips were so long and twisted that the poor little peoplelooked quite hideous.

context: So she mentioned first one name and then another, always pretending to think that she had hit upon the right one; and all the time the PeerieBoy jumped from side to side with delight, for he thought that she would never find out the right name, and that half of the cloth would be his.But at last the Princess grew tired of joking, and she cried out, with alittle laugh of triumph, "Do you by any chance know anyone calledPEERIFOOL, little Mannikin?"Then he knew that in some way she had found out what men called him, and he was so angry and disappointed that he flung the webs of cloth down in a heap on the floor, and ran out at the door, slamming it behind him.Meanwhile the Giant was coming down the hill in the darkening, and, to his astonishment, he met a troop of little Peerie Folk toiling up it,looking as if they were so tired that they could hardly get along. Theireyes were dim and listless, their heads were hanging on their breasts,and their lips were so long and twisted that the poor little peoplelooked quite hideous.The Giant asked how this was, and they told him that they had to work sohard all day, spinning for their Master that they were quite exhausted;and that the reason why their lips were so distorted was that they usedthem constantly to wet their fingers, so that they might pull the woolin very fine strands from the distaff."I always thought a great deal of women who could spin," said the Giant,"and I looked out for a housewife that could do so. But after this Iwill be more careful, for the housewife that I have now is a bonnielittle woman, and I would be loth to have her spoil her face in thatmanner."And he hurried home in a great state of mind in case he should find thathis new servant's pretty red lips had grown long and ugly in hisabsence.

qas.question: Why were the Peerie Folk's lips so distorted?
qas.answer: They used them constantly to wet their fingers, so that they might pull the wool in very fine strands from the distaff. .

context: Great was his relief to see her standing by the table, bonnie andwinsome as ever, with all the webs of cloth in a pile in front of her."By my truth, you are an industrious maiden," he said, in high goodhumour, "and, as a reward for working so diligently, I will restore yoursisters to you." And he went out to the byre, and lifted the two otherPrincesses down from the rafters, and brought them in and laid them on the settle.Their little sister nearly screamed aloud when she saw how ill theylooked and how bruised their backs were, but, like a prudent maiden, she held her tongue, and busied herself with applying a cooling ointment to their wounds, and binding them up, and by and by her sisters revived, and, after the Giant had gone to bed, they told her all that had befallen them.

context: "I will be avenged on him for his cruelty," said the little Princessfirmly; and when she spoke like that her sisters knew that she meantwhat she said.So next morning, before the Giant was up, she fetched his creel, and put her eldest sister into it, and covered her with all the fine silkenhangings and tapestry that she could find, and on the top of all she puta handful of grass, and when the Giant came downstairs she asked him, in her sweetest tone, if he would do her a favour.And the Giant, who was very pleased with her because of the quantity of cloth which he thought she had spun, said that he would."Then carry that creelful of grass home to my mother's cottage for hercow to eat," said the Princess. "This will help to make up for all thecabbages which you have stolen from her kailyard."And, wonderful to relate, the Giant did as he was bid, and carried thecreel to the cottage.Next morning she put her second sister into another creel, and coveredher with all the fine napery she could find in the house, and put anarmful of grass on the top of it, and at her bidding the Giant, who wasreally getting very fond of her, carried it also home to her mother.The next morning the little Princess told him that she thought that shewould go for a long walk after she had done her housework, and that she might not be in when he came home at night, but that she would have Another creel of grass ready for him, if he would carry it to thecottage as he had done on the two previous evenings. He promised to do so; then, as usual, he went out for the day.In the afternoon the clever little maiden went through the house,gathering together all the lace, and silver, and jewellery that shecould find, and brought them and placed them beside the creel. Then she went out and cut an armful of grass, and brought it in and laid itbeside them.Then she crept into the creel herself, and pulled all the fine things inabove her, and then she covered everything up with the grass, which was a very difficult thing to do, seeing she herself was at the bottom ofthe basket. Then she lay quite still and waited.Presently the Giant came in, and, obedient to his promise, he lifted thecreel and carried it off to the old Queen's cottage.No one seemed to be at home, so he set it down in the entry, and turned to go away. But the little Princess had told her sisters what to do, and they had a great can of boiling water ready in one of the roomsupstairs, and when they heard his steps coming round that side of thehouse, they threw open the window and emptied it all over his head; and that was the end of him.

qas.question: How did the youngest Princess take revenge on the Giant?
qas.answer: She tricked him. .

abstract_70: A determined little Princess vowed to take revenge on a Giant for his cruelty, speaking with such firmness that her sisters knew she meant every word. She devised an ingenious plan involving three creels (baskets). On the first morning, before the Giant awoke, she placed her eldest sister in a creel, carefully concealing her with all the fine silken hangings and tapestry she could find in the house, topping it with a handful of grass. When the Giant came downstairs, she asked him sweetly if he would do her a favor. The Giant, being quite pleased with her due to what he believed was her extensive cloth spinning, readily agreed. She requested him to carry the creelful of grass to her mother's cottage for her cow, claiming it would compensate for all the cabbages he had stolen from the kailyard. Remarkably, the Giant complied. The next morning, she implemented the same strategy with her second sister, hiding her under all the fine napery available in the house and covering it with grass. The Giant, who had grown quite fond of her by this time, willingly carried this creel as well. On the third day, the Princess informed him she might take a long walk after her housework and be absent when he returned, but promised another creel would be ready for delivery. After he left, she meticulously gathered every valuable item in the house - all the lace, silver, and jewellery she could find - and brought them beside the creel. She then collected an armful of grass and, in a challenging maneuver, managed to conceal herself at the bottom of the creel, covering herself with the treasures and grass. When the Giant delivered the final creel to the cottage, no one appeared to be home. However, her sisters were prepared with a large can of boiling water, following her instructions precisely. As the Giant turned to leave and his footsteps approached the side of the house, they threw open the upstairs window and emptied the boiling water over him, bringing about his demise.
abstract_30: A clever Princess sought revenge against a cruel Giant. She devised a plan to save her sisters and herself by tricking the Giant into carrying them home in creels. On consecutive days, she concealed her eldest sister and second sister in baskets, covering them with fine fabrics and grass, which the Giant unknowingly delivered to their mother's cottage. Finally, the Princess hid herself in a creel filled with valuable items and grass. When the Giant delivered the last basket, her sisters were ready with boiling water, which they poured over him, ultimately ending his tyranny.
fully_response: The youngest Princess tricked the Giant into carrying her and her sisters back to their mother's cottage in baskets disguised as grass. On the third day, after she was delivered, her sisters poured boiling water on the Giant, killing him and avenging his cruelty.

On the final day, she hid herself in a creel along with valuables from the Giant's house, and when the Giant delivered it to the cottage, her sisters poured boiling water on him, killing him.

context: Once upon a time there lived a king who was deeply in love with a princess, but she could not marry anyone, because she was under an enchantment. So the King set out to seek a fairy, and asked what he could do to win the Princess's love. The Fairy said to him:  "You know that the Princess has a great cat which she is very fond of. Whoever is clever enough to tread on that cat's tail is the man she is destined to marry."At last, however, he was lucky enough to come upon puss fast asleep and with his tail conveniently spread out. So the King, without losing a moment, set his foot upon it heavily.  With one terrific yell the cat sprang up and instantly changed into a tall man, who, fixing his angry eyes upon the King, said:  "You shall marry the Princess because you have been able to break the enchantment, but I will have my revenge. You shall have a son, who will never be happy until he finds out that his nose is too long, and if you ever tell anyone what I have just said to you, you shall vanish away instantly, and no one shall ever see you or hear of you again."  Though the King was horribly afraid of the enchanter, he could not help laughing at this threat.  "If my son has such a long nose as that," he said to himself, "he must always see it or feel it; at least, if he is not blind or without hands."

qas.question: Why didn't the princess marry anyone?
qas.answer: She was under an enchantment. .

abstract_70: Once there lived a king who deeply loved a princess, but she was under an enchantment that prevented her marriage. The king sought out a fairy for guidance on winning the princess's love. The fairy informed him that the princess had a beloved cat, and whoever managed to step on the cat's tail would be destined to marry her. After much waiting, the king finally discovered the cat sleeping with its tail conveniently stretched out. Without hesitation, he firmly stepped on it. The cat let out a tremendous yell and transformed into a tall man - an enchanter - who fixed angry eyes upon the king. He declared that while the king could marry the princess for breaking the enchantment, his revenge would be that the king's future son would remain unhappy until he realized his nose was too long. The enchanter added that if the king ever revealed this conversation, he would instantly vanish forever. Though terrified of the enchanter, the king couldn't help but find humor in this threat, thinking to himself that such a long nose would be impossible for his son to overlook unless he was blind or had no hands.
abstract_30: A king sought to marry an enchanted princess who could only wed someone capable of stepping on her beloved cat's tail. After successfully doing so, the cat transformed into an enchanter who granted the king permission to marry the princess. However, the enchanter cursed the king's future son to remain unhappy until he discovered his unusually long nose, and threatened the king with disappearance if he ever revealed this secret.
fully_response: The princess didn't marry anyone because she was under an enchantment that prevented her from doing so.

context: Once upon a time there lived a king who was deeply in love with a princess, but she could not marry anyone, because she was under an enchantment. So the King set out to seek a fairy, and asked what he could do to win the Princess's love. The Fairy said to him:  "You know that the Princess has a great cat which she is very fond of. Whoever is clever enough to tread on that cat's tail is the man she is destined to marry."The King said to himself that this would not be very difficult, and he left the Fairy, determined to grind the cat's tail to powder rather than not tread on it at all.  You may imagine that it was not long before he went to see the Princess, and puss, as usual, marched in before him, arching his back. The King took a long step, and quite thought he had the tail under his foot, but the cat turned round so sharply that he only trod on air. And so it went on for eight days, till the King began to think that this fatal tail must be full of quicksilver-it was never still for a moment.At last, however, he was lucky enough to come upon puss fast asleep and with his tail conveniently spread out. So the King, without losing a moment, set his foot upon it heavily.  With one terrific yell the cat sprang up and instantly changed into a tall man, who, fixing his angry eyes upon the King, said:  "You shall marry the Princess because you have been able to break the enchantment, but I will have my revenge. You shall have a son, who will never be happy until he finds out that his nose is too long, and if you ever tell anyone what I have just said to you, you shall vanish away instantly, and no one shall ever see you or hear of you again."  Though the King was horribly afraid of the enchanter, he could not help laughing at this threat.  "If my son has such a long nose as that," he said to himself, "he must always see it or feel it; at least, if he is not blind or without hands."

qas.question: Why did the king set his foot upon the cat's tail heavily even though it was fast asleep?
qas.answer: He wanted to break the princess's enchantment. .

abstract_70: Once there lived a king who deeply loved a princess, but she was bound by an enchantment that prevented her marriage. The king sought help from a fairy, who revealed that whoever could step on her beloved cat's tail would be destined to marry the princess. The king, thinking this task would be simple, was determined to succeed at any cost. He visited the princess, where the cat would always walk in front of him with an arched back. For eight days, the king attempted to step on the cat's tail, but the clever creature always managed to evade him, making the king wonder if the tail contained quicksilver due to its constant movement. Finally, fortune smiled upon him when he found the cat fast asleep with its tail conveniently stretched out. The king quickly seized the opportunity and stepped firmly on the tail. With a tremendous yell, the cat transformed into a tall enchanter who, with angry eyes, declared that while the king could marry the princess for breaking the spell, there would be revenge: the king's future son would remain unhappy until he discovered his nose was too long. The enchanter added that if the king ever revealed this secret, he would vanish forever without a trace. Despite being terrified of the enchanter, the king couldn't help but laugh at the threat, reasoning that such a long nose would be impossible for his son to overlook.
abstract_30: A king sought to marry a princess who was under an enchantment. A fairy informed him that he must step on her beloved cat's tail to win her hand. After several failed attempts, the king finally succeeded when the cat was sleeping. The cat transformed into an enchanter, who declared that while the king could marry the princess, his revenge would be that their future son would be unhappy until he discovered his nose was too long. The enchanter also warned that if the king ever revealed this secret, he would disappear forever.
fully_response: The King set his foot heavily on the cat's tail because he had struggled for days to step on it while the cat was awake and moving. When he found the cat asleep with its tail exposed, he seized the opportunity to finally tread on it and break the enchantment, ensuring he wouldn't fail again.
roughly_response: The king set his foot upon the cat's tail heavily because the Fairy had told him that whoever treads on the cat's tail would be the one destined to marry the Princess. Seeing the cat fast asleep with its tail conveniently spread out, the king seized the opportunity to fulfill the condition and break the enchantment, ensuring he could marry the Princess.
abstract_response: The king stepped heavily on the cat's tail because he saw it as his only opportunity to fulfill the fairy's condition—stepping on the tail would break the enchantment and allow him to marry the princess. Even though the cat was asleep, he wanted to ensure he didn’t miss his chance, as the cat had previously been too quick to evade him.
partially_response: The king stepped on the cat's tail heavily because the fairy had told him that doing so was the condition to break the enchantment and win the princess's hand in marriage. Even though the cat was asleep, he needed to fulfill this requirement to succeed.
blank_response: The king likely did it accidentally or without noticing the cat.

context: When he grew sensible he learned history; and whenever any great prince or beautiful princess was spoken of, his teachers took care to tell him that they had long noses.  His room was hung with pictures, all of people with very large noses; and the Prince grew up so convinced that a long nose was a great beauty, that he would not on any account have had his own a single inch shorter!  When his twentieth birthday was passed the Queen thought it was time that he should be married, so she commanded that the portraits of several princesses should be brought for him to see, and among the others was a picture of the Dear Little Princess!

qas.question: Why did the prince's room have pictures with all of people with very large noses?
qas.answer: Prince grew up so convinced that a long nose was a great beauty. .

qas.question: Why did the queen command that the portraits of several princesses should be brought for the prince to see?
qas.answer: The Queen thought it was time that he should be married. .

His chambers were decorated with portraits of people bearing large noses, leading him to believe that long noses were the epitome of beauty. The queen commanded that portraits of princesses be brought for the prince to see because she believed it was time for him to marry, and this was the traditional way to select a suitable bride for him.

context: At last, however, he was lucky enough to come upon puss fast asleep and with his tail conveniently spread out. So the King, without losing a moment, set his foot upon it heavily.  With one terrific yell the cat sprang up and instantly changed into a tall man, who, fixing his angry eyes upon the King, said:  "You shall marry the Princess because you have been able to break the enchantment, but I will have my revenge. You shall have a son, who will never be happy until he finds out that his nose is too long, and if you ever tell anyone what I have just said to you, you shall vanish away instantly, and no one shall ever see you or hear of you again."  Though the King was horribly afraid of the enchanter, he could not help laughing at this threat.  "If my son has such a long nose as that," he said to himself, "he must always see it or feel it; at least, if he is not blind or without hands."The Prince made him a splendid present as a reward for this good news, and at once sent ambassadors to ask the Dear Little Princess in marriage. The King, her father, gave his consent; and Prince Hyacinth, who, in his anxiety to see the Princess, had gone three leagues to meet her was just advancing to kiss her hand when, to the horror of all who stood by, the enchanter appeared as suddenly as a flash of lightning, and, snatching up the Dear Little Princess, whirled her away out of their sight!

qas.question: Why did the enchanter appear as suddenly as a flash of lightning and snatch up the Dear Little Princess?
qas.answer: The enchanter wanted his revenge on the prince's father. .

abstract_70: The King discovered a sleeping cat and stepped on its tail, causing it to transform into a tall man. The enchanter, with angry eyes, declared that while the King would marry the Princess for breaking the spell, he would have his revenge: the King's future son would never be happy until discovering his long nose. He warned that if the King revealed this curse, he would vanish forever. Though frightened, the King found humor in the threat, reasoning that such a long nose would be impossible to miss unless his son was blind or handless. Later, Prince Hyacinth, after receiving good news, sent ambassadors to request the Dear Little Princess's hand in marriage. With her father's consent, the Prince traveled three leagues to meet her, but just as he was about to kiss her hand, the enchanter suddenly appeared and whisked the Princess away.
abstract_30: A king encounters a sleeping cat and steps on its tail, causing it to transform into an enchanter. The enchanter, angered, declares that while the king will marry the Princess, his revenge will be that the king's future son will remain unhappy until he discovers his nose is too long. The king finds this amusing but is warned not to reveal this curse. Later, when Prince Hyacinth attempts to marry the Dear Little Princess, the enchanter suddenly appears and kidnaps her, disappearing instantly.
fully_response: The enchanter appeared suddenly and snatched the Dear Little Princess as an act of revenge against the King for breaking the enchantment on the cat (the enchanter's previous form). This was part of his threat to ensure the King's son, Prince Hyacinth, would suffer unhappiness.
roughly_response: The enchanter appeared suddenly and snatched up the Dear Little Princess to exact his revenge on the King, as he had previously threatened. The King had broken the enchantment by stepping on the cat's tail, which angered the enchanter, and this was part of his retaliation.
abstract_response: The enchanter appeared suddenly and snatched the Dear Little Princess to fulfill his earlier threat of revenge against the King. He had warned that the King's future son (Prince Hyacinth) would never be happy until discovering his long nose, and his abrupt interference during the Prince's meeting with the Princess was part of this curse.
partially_response: The enchanter appeared suddenly and snatched the Dear Little Princess as an act of revenge, fulfilling the curse he had placed on the king's future son (Prince Hyacinth) to ensure his unhappiness until he discovered his nose was too long.
blank_response: To create conflict and drive the story's plot forward.

context: The Prince was left quite unconsolable, and declared that nothing should induce him to go back to his kingdom until he had found her again, and refusing to allow any of his courtiers to follow him, he mounted his horse and rode sadly away, letting the animal choose his own path.  So it happened that he came presently to a great plain, across which he rode all day long without seeing a single house, and horse and rider were terribly hungry, when, as the night fell, the Prince caught sight of a light, which seemed to shine from a cavern.  He rode up to it, and saw a little old woman, who appeared to be at least a hundred years old.  She put on her spectacles to look at Prince Hyacinth, but it was quite a long time before she could fix them securely because her nose was so very short.

qas.question: Who did the prince see when he caught sight of a light, which seemed to shine from a cavern?
qas.answer: a little old woman .

abstract_70: The Prince, devastated and refusing companionship, embarked on a solitary journey to find someone, letting his horse guide the way. After riding across a vast plain all day without encountering any dwellings, both he and his horse grew hungry. As darkness approached, he spotted a light from a cavern where he discovered an ancient woman, seemingly a centenarian. She struggled to wear her spectacles to examine Prince Hyacinth, hampered by her unusually short nose.
abstract_30: A distraught Prince set out alone to find his lost love, eventually discovering a cavern where he encountered a very old woman with an unusually short nose.
fully_response: The prince saw a little old woman, who appeared to be at least a hundred years old, when he caught sight of a light shining from a cavern.

context: The Prince and the Fairy (for that was who she was) had no sooner looked at one another than they went into fits of laughter, and cried at the same moment, "Oh, what a funny nose!"  "Not so funny as your own," said Prince Hyacinth to the Fairy; "but, madam, I beg you to leave the consideration of our noses-such as they are-and to be good enough to give me something to eat, for I am starving, and so is my poor horse."  "With all my heart," said the Fairy. "Though your nose is so ridiculous you are, nevertheless, the son of my best friend. I loved your father as if he had been my brother. Now he had a very handsome nose!"  "And pray what does mine lack?" said the Prince.  "Oh! it doesn't lack anything," replied the Fairy. "On the contrary quite, there is only too much of it. But never mind, one may be a very worthy man though his nose is too long. I was telling you that I was your father's friend; he often came to see me in the old times, and you must know that I was very pretty in those days; at least, he used to say so. I should like to tell you of a conversation we had the last time I ever saw him."  "Indeed," said the Prince, "when I have supped it will give me the greatest pleasure to hear it; but consider, madam, I beg of you, that I have had nothing to eat to-day."In an instant the crystal prison flew into a thousand splinters, and the old Fairy, taking the Dear Little Princess by the hand, said to the Prince:  "Now, say if you are not very much obliged to me. Much good it was for me to talk to you about your nose! You would never have found out how extraordinary it was if it hadn't hindered you from doing what you wanted to. You see how self-love keeps us from knowing our own defects of mind and body. Our reason tries in vain to show them to us; we refuse to see them till we find them in the way of our interests."  Prince Hyacinth, whose nose was now just like anyone's else, did not fail to profit by the lesson he had received. He married the Dear Little Princess, and they lived happily ever after.

qas.question: Why did the old fairy wish to make the prince happy and hit upon a plan?
qas.answer: He was the son of the old fairy's best friend. .

abstract_70: Upon meeting, Prince Hyacinth and the Fairy (for that was who she was) immediately burst into fits of laughter, both exclaiming about the peculiarity of each other's noses. The Prince, who was starving along with his horse, requested food from the Fairy, insisting his nose wasn't as funny as hers. She warmly welcomed him, explaining that despite his ridiculous nose, he was the son of her dearest friend whom she loved like a brother. The Fairy mentioned that his father, who had a very handsome nose, used to visit her frequently in the past when she was considered quite pretty, at least according to his father's words. When she attempted to share a story about their last conversation, the Prince politely reminded her of his urgent need for food, having eaten nothing all day. The tale reaches its dramatic climax when a crystal prison suddenly shatters into a thousand splinters, and the Fairy, taking the Dear Little Princess by the hand, delivers a profound lesson about self-awareness. She explains how self-love blinds people from recognizing their own physical and mental flaws, and how human reason tries in vain to show these defects, which we refuse to acknowledge until they directly interfere with our interests. The story concludes with Prince Hyacinth, whose nose had finally become just like anyone else's, taking this valuable lesson to heart. He then marries the Dear Little Princess, and they live happily ever after.
abstract_30: A Prince with an unusually long nose meets a Fairy who was his father's friend. Initially, they laugh at each other's noses, but the Fairy welcomes him despite his unusual feature. Through a series of events (involving a crystal prison and a Dear Little Princess), the Prince learns an important lesson about self-awareness and how personal flaws often remain unnoticed until they interfere with our desires. The Fairy helps him understand this truth, his nose becomes normal, and he ultimately marries the Princess, leading to a happy ending. The story serves as a moral tale about self-love and the importance of recognizing one's own defects.
fully_response: The old Fairy wished to make the Prince happy because she was a dear friend of his father and held affection for him. She devised a plan to teach him a lesson about self-awareness and humility, knowing that overcoming his vanity (symbolized by his long nose) would lead to his personal growth and eventual happiness, including his marriage to the Dear Little Princess.
roughly_response: The old fairy wished to make the prince happy and hit upon a plan because she was a friend of his father and loved him as if he were her brother. She wanted to help the prince realize his own flaw (his overly long nose) through a lesson, as self-love often prevents people from recognizing their defects until those defects interfere with their desires or interests.
abstract_response: The old fairy wished to make the prince happy because he was the son of her dearest friend, whom she loved like a brother. She hit upon a plan to help him, likely due to her affection for his father and her desire to assist the prince in overcoming his flaws and finding happiness.
partially_response: The old fairy wished to make the prince happy because she was a friend of his father and cared for him. She hit upon a plan to teach him an important lesson about self-awareness and recognizing his own flaws, which ultimately led to his happiness and a happy ending with the princess.
blank_response: The old fairy wanted to reward the prince's kindness with joy.

context: The old Fairy, who wished to make him happy, at last hit upon a plan. She shut the Dear Little Princess up in a palace of crystal, and put this palace down where the Prince would not fail to find it. His joy at seeing the Princess again was extreme, and he set to work with all his might to try to break her prison; but in spite of all his efforts he failed utterly. In despair he thought at least that he would try to get near enough to speak to the Dear Little Princess, who, on her part, stretched out her hand that he might kiss it; but turn which way he might, he never could raise it to his lips, for his long nose always prevented it. For the first time he realized how long it really was, and exclaimed:  "Well, it must be admitted that my nose is too long!"

context: "My dear Prince, might I beg you to move a little more that way, for your nose casts such a shadow that I really cannot see what I have on my plate. Ah! thanks. Now let us speak of your father. When I went to his Court he was only a little boy, but that is forty years ago, and I have been in this desolate place ever since. Tell me what goes on nowadays; are the ladies as fond of amusement as ever? In my time one saw them at parties, theatres, balls, and promenades every day. Dear me! what a long nose you have! I cannot get used to it!"  "Really, madam," said the Prince, "I wish you would leave off mentioning my nose. It cannot matter to you what it is like. I am quite satisfied with it, and have no wish to have it shorter. One must take what is given one."  "Now you are angry with me, my poor Hyacinth," said the Fairy, "and I assure you that I didn't mean to vex you; on the contrary, I wished to do you a service. However, though I really cannot help your nose being a shock to me, I will try not to say anything about it. I will even try to think that you have an ordinary nose. To tell the truth, it would make three reasonable ones."

qas.question: How did the prince feel about his nose?
qas.answer: He was quite satisfied with it. .

The little Prince had large blue eyes, the prettiest eyes in the world, and a sweet little mouth, but, alas! his nose was so enormous that it covered half his face. The Queen was inconsolable when she saw this great nose, but her ladies assured her that it was not really as large as it looked; that it was a Roman nose, and you had only to open any history to see that every hero has a large nose. The Queen, who was devoted to her baby, was pleased with what they told her, and when she looked at Hyacinth again, his nose certainly did not seem to her quite so large.

abstract_30: A king encounters a sleeping cat and breaks its enchantment by stepping on its tail. The cat transforms into a man who declares that while the king may marry the Princess, his revenge will be that the king's son will be unhappy until he realizes his nose is too long. After the king's marriage and subsequent death, his son Prince Hyacinth is born with an extraordinarily large nose. The Queen is initially distressed by this, but her ladies comfort her by suggesting it's a noble Roman nose, characteristic of heroes.
fully_response: The Queen didn't know the reason for her son's enormous nose because the King never told her about the enchanter's curse, as doing so would have caused him to vanish instantly. The King died without revealing the secret, leaving the Queen unaware of the prophecy.
roughly_response: The queen did not know the reason for her son's enormous nose because the enchanter's threat prevented the King from telling anyone about the curse. The King vanished when he revealed the enchanter's words, so he could not explain the reason to the queen.
abstract_response: The queen didn't know the reason for her son's enormous nose because the King never revealed the enchanter's warning. The enchanter had threatened that if the King ever disclosed their conversation, he would instantly vanish forever. Since the King kept this secret, the queen remained unaware of the curse placed on their son.
partially_response: The queen did not know the reason for her son's enormous nose because the enchanted cat's curse was only revealed to the king, not to her. The cat's declaration about the king's son being unhappy due to his long nose was made to the king alone, and this information was not passed on to the queen.
blank_response: She was blind to his flaws due to love.

context: But, as the enchanter had vanished, he did not waste any more time in thinking, but went to seek the Princess, who very soon consented to marry him. But after all, they had not been married very long when the King died, and the Queen had nothing left to care for but her little son, who was called Hyacinth. The little Prince had large blue eyes, the prettiest eyes in the world, and a sweet little mouth, but, alas! his nose was so enormous that it covered half his face. The Queen was inconsolable when she saw this great nose, but her ladies assured her that it was not really as large as it looked; that it was a Roman nose, and you had only to open any history to see that every hero has a large nose. The Queen, who was devoted to her baby, was pleased with what they told her, and when she looked at Hyacinth again, his nose certainly did not seem to her quite so large.

qas.question: Why did the queen look at the prince again and believe his nose was not so large?
qas.answer: Her ladies assured her that it was not really as large as it looked; that it was a Roman nose, and you had only to open any history to see that every hero has a large nose. .

context: There was to be a great battle between all the creatures of the earth and the birds of the air. News of it went abroad, and the son of the king of Tethertown said that when the battle was fought he would be there to see it, and would bring back word who was to be king. But in spite of that, he was almost too late, and every fight had been fought save the last, which was between a snake and a great black raven. Both struck hard, but in the end the snake proved the stronger, and would have twisted himself round the neck of the raven till he died had not the king's son drawn his sword, and cut off the head of the snake at a single blow. And when the raven beheld that his enemy was dead, he was grateful, and said:  'For thy kindness to me this day, I will show thee a sight. So come up now on the root of my two wings.' The king's son did as he was bid, and before the raven stopped flying, they had passed over seven bens and seven glens and seven mountain moors.  'Do you see that house yonder?' said the raven at last. 'Go straight for it, for a sister of mine dwells there, and she will make you right welcome. And if she asks, "Wert thou at the battle of the birds?" answer that thou wert, and if she asks, "Didst thou see my likeness?" answer that thou sawest it, but be sure thou meetest me in the morning at this place.'

context: The king's son followed what the raven told him and that night he had meat of each meat, and drink of each drink, warm water for his feet, and a soft bed to lie in.  Thus it happened the next day, and the next, but on the fourth meeting, instead of meeting the raven, in his place the king's son found waiting for him the handsomest youth that ever was seen, with a bundle in his hand.  'Is there a raven hereabouts?' asked the king's son, and the youth answered:  'I am that raven, and I was delivered by thee from the spells that bound me, and in reward thou wilt get this bundle. Go back by the road thou camest, and lie as before, a night in each house, but be careful not to unloose the bundle till thou art in the place wherein thou wouldst most wish to dwell.'  Then the king's son set out, and thus it happened as it had happened before, till he entered a thick wood near his father's house. He had walked a long way and suddenly the bundle seemed to grow heavier; first he put it down under a tree, and next he thought he would look at it.

context: The string was easy to untie, and the king's son soon unfastened the bundle. What was it he saw there? Why, a great castle with an orchard all about it, and in the orchard fruit and flowers and birds of very kind. It was all ready for him to dwell in, but instead of being in the midst of the forest, he did wish he had left the bundle unloosed till he had reached the green valley close to his father's palace. Well, it was no use wishing, and with a sigh he glanced up, and beheld a huge giant coming towards him.  'Bad is the place where thou hast built thy house, king's son,' said the giant.  'True; it is not here that I wish to be,' answered the king's son.  'What reward wilt thou give me if I put it back in the bundle?' asked the giant.  'What reward dost thou ask?' answered the king's son.  'The first boy thou hast when he is seven years old,' said the giant.  'If I have a boy thou shalt get him,' answered the king's son, and as he spoke the castle and the orchard were tied up in the bundle again.  'Now take thy road, and I will take mine,' said the giant. 'And if thou forgettest thy promise, I will remember it.'
